awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: Scalable Dynamic Access Control for Untrusted Cloud Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
When users store their data in the cloud, they take many privacy risks: Will the cloud storage provider allow others to see that data? If the user sets sharing rules for the data, will the cloud storage system follow those rules? Recent news stories of user data exfiltration from cloud storage systems show that users have reason for concern.  Encrypting files before storing them in the cloud would provide strong protection, but this approach makes it very difficult for users to share data with others and to change their sharing policies. This project is exploring techniques to cryptographically protect user files in cloud-based storage systems, while supporting advanced, dynamic sharing policies.

While cryptographically protecting data under a static access control policy is well documented in the literature, existing constructions either do not efficiently support dynamic policies (e.g., changes to role/attribute assignments) or make heavy trust assumptions to support this dynamism.  This project is (1) developing an open-source platform for prototyping, analyzing, and deploying dynamic access control enforcement solutions for untrusted environments; (2) creating cryptographic constructions that are capable of securely implementing popular role- and attribute-based access control models on untrusted storage platforms while supporting dynamic policy and data updates; (3) designing efficient, trusted hardware-assisted, cloud-scale implementations of popular access control models supporting dynamic policy and data updates in a variety of deployment scenarios; and (4) a carrying out a comprehensive evaluation that explores the trade-offs in trust between these cryptographically- and hardware-enforced approaches and examines the cryptographic, computational, and communication costs of the proposed constructions under a variety of real-world workloads.

por.por_cntn:
There are significant risks in storing sensitive data on the cloud, with regular news stories of data being exfiltrated from cloud providers, resulting in significant societal harm and fiscal costs. This project aims to bring advanced access control systems to cloud-based file storage systems, such that data can be shared in ways that modern organizations and users expect, all while ensuring that the data itself is never exposed to unauthorized entities except in encrypted form. While cryptographically protecting data under a static access control policy is well documented in the literature, existing constructions either do not efficiently support dynamic policies (e.g., changes to role/attribute assignments) or make heavy trust assumptions to support this dynamism. The goal of this project was to protect user, corporate, and governmental data stored on the cloud from malicious cloud providers and exfiltration attacks on said providers, all while efficiently supporting dynamic modifications to both access control policies and the data itself. The proposed approaches made use of modern cryptography and newly available commodity trusted computing hardware to develop, measure, and deploy systems that have dynamic expressive access controls.

 

In the context of traditional file systems, we have developed prototype systems that are optimized for both user- and server-class workloads.  Our Nexus platform is a stackable filesystem that leverages trusted hardware to provide confidentiality and integrity for user files stored on untrusted platforms. NEXUS is explicitly designed to balance security, portability, and performance: it supports dynamic sharing of protected volumes on any platform exposing a file access API without requiring server-side support, enables the use of fine-grained access control policies to allow for selective sharing, and avoids the key revocation and file re-encryption overheads associated with other cryptographic approaches to access control.  While this decentralized approach provides flexibility for users, it comes with steep metadata costs for more distributed workloads making it less suitable for server-class workloads.  Our MooseGuard prototype extends the MooseFS high-performance distributed file system by leveraging a TEE inside the storage service backend to handle metadata operations. This removed the need for a distributed synchronization approach that introduced substantial overheads to ensure metadata consistency. The addition of a server-side TEE allowed us to provide the same security guarantees as Nexus at large scale at the cost of service portability and architecture generality. 

 

In the context of more emergent applications, we explored the use of TEE-based access controls in the context of web photo management through our Seabrook prototype, and used this use case to better understand how users’ mental models of TEEs play into their selection of photo redaction approaches.  We additionally explored the use of TEEs in the context of data protection in smart environments.  Our findings show that TEEs significantly increase user comfort across information flows. These increases are more pronounced for smaller device vendors and show that TEEs can bridge the previously-documented gulfs in user trust between small and large device manufacturers. Sentiments around consent, bystander data, and indefinite retention are unaffected by the presence of TEEs, indicating the centrality of these norms.

 

In addition, this work explored the capabilities of a range of available trusted computing hardware architectures, and investigated high level abstractions and distributed service architectures to support a trusted execution environment across a heterogeneous collection of diverse hardware platforms. These efforts were able to support initial efforts to extend the privacy controls we developed from cloud based environments to edge and Internet-of-Things (IoT) system deployments. As a result of these efforts we were able to formulate requirements and develop strategies to empower users to take control of their personal privacy across large scale information collections and processing ecosystems. These results provided the foundation that has allowed us to continue exploring trusted privacy enforcement across large scale distributed environments consisting of edge and IoT infrastructure.
